Here are 6 things you learned in school that you'll need to unlearn when building software products 
 
School: Avoid D's and F's at all costs  
 
Building products: Fail often. Fail fast. Learn faster. 
 
School: You can get a perfect score  
 
Building products: Perfection is a myth. Prioritize progress. 
 
School: Work toward the big "launch" 
 
Building products: Launch fast and iterate.  
 
School: Success is a solo game and hard work  
 
Building products: Success is a team sport.  
 
Collaboration and influence matter more than intelligence or effort. 
 
School: The rules for success are crystal clear  
 
Building products: You define what success and failure look like.

School: The rules for success are crystal clear  
 
Building products: You define what success and failure look like.  
 
School: Follow the curriculum and you’ll be fine  
 
Building products: There’s no set path.  
 
Success often comes from exploring uncharted territory. 
 
Unlearning these takes time.  
 
I’m still undoing old habits that don’t serve me in the real world. And I’m building products since... a long time ;) 
 
What else have you had to unlearn while building products? Let’s share insights.

7 gold principles of SaaS design

(They keep your users coming back):

𝟭. 𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗪𝗶𝗻𝘀

Complexity kills engagement. 

Every click should feel natural and easy. 

Simplify the interface, and you'll simplify the user's decision-making process.

𝟮. 𝗦𝗽𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝗶𝘀 𝗞𝗶𝗻𝗴

Users hate waiting. 

If your app isn't lightning-fast, they'll leave. 

Optimize load times relentlessly. Faster experiences mean happier users.

𝟯.

Optimize load times relentlessly. Faster experiences mean happier users.

𝟯. 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗕𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴

Your design should echo your brand’s voice everywhere. 

Consistency builds trust, and trust keeps users coming back.

𝟰.

Consistency builds trust, and trust keeps users coming back.

𝟰. 𝗨𝘀𝗲𝗿-𝗖𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰 𝗡𝗮𝘃𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

Design with the user's journey in mind.

Predict their next move and make it easy for them to find what they need. 

If they get lost, they'll leave.

𝟱. 𝗙𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝗟𝗼𝗼𝗽𝘀

Don’t leave users guessing.

Whether it's a button click or a loading screen, always show that the system is responding. 

Silence frustrates. Feedback reassures.

𝟲. 𝗔𝗱𝗮𝗽𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆

Your SaaS should look and work great on any device.

Ensure a seamless experience across platforms.

𝟳. 𝗜𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗘𝘃𝗼𝗹𝘃𝗲

User needs change, so should your design. 

Regularly update your interface based on feedback and analytics.

Regularly update your interface based on feedback and analytics. 

Evolution keeps your product relevant.

Following these principles isn’t just about good design; it’s about creating an experience that users can’t resist. Implement them, and you’ll see the loyalty grow.

6 things developers wish to say to UI designers: 
 
1. "𝗦𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗸 𝘁𝗼 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗻𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 (𝗽𝗹𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗲!)" 
 
Misnamed files wreak havoc.  
 
Consistency in naming all layers, styles, and components is key.

Misnamed files wreak havoc.  
 
Consistency in naming all layers, styles, and components is key.  
 
Think of it like labeling your kitchen utensils—easy to find and ready to use, every time. 
 
(If you’re not labeling them—what are you even doing?!) 
 
𝟮. "𝗗𝗼𝗻'𝘁 𝗮𝘀𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝘄𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄" 
 
Don't assume we understand the tiny details that seem obvious to you.  
 
Document every nuance: margins, padding, font sizes, colors.  
 
Annotate as if you're writing instructions for a stranger. 
 
𝟯.

Annotate as if you're writing instructions for a stranger. 
 
𝟯. "𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁 𝗮𝘀𝘀𝗲𝘁𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗽𝗲𝗿 𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝘁𝘀—𝘁𝗿𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗺𝗲, 𝗶𝘁 𝘀𝗮𝘃𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲."

We need assets in the required formats: SVG, PNG, high-res, low-res.  
 
Double-check file specs before exporting.  
 
A small act that saves us tons of time. 
 
𝟰. "𝗥𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘁𝘀" 
 
Your design is beautiful—and it hurts our dev hearts if we can’t possibly code it. 
 
Be mindful of what is feasible technically.

Be mindful of what is feasible technically.  
 
It's not about limiting creativity, but optimizing it. 
 
𝟱. "𝗗𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗼𝗳𝗳—𝗰𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲" 
 
Don't just hand off your work and vanish.  
 
Continuous collaboration ensures we're on the same page, solving issues together in real-time. 
 
𝟲.

Continuous collaboration ensures we're on the same page, solving issues together in real-time. 
 
𝟲. "𝗦𝗽𝗲𝗰𝗶𝗳𝘆 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗹𝘆—𝗜 𝗵𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗴𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴!" 
 
Interactions and animations need clarity, not guesswork.

Interactions and animations need clarity, not guesswork.  
 
Specify behaviors, transitions, and states.  
 
The more explicit, the better. 
 
Follow these rules, and you'll have developers singing your praises.  
 
Let's make handoffs something to look forward to.

The bulletproof system we used to help pinqDR Dispute Resolution bring their product idea to life: 
 
Having a clear roadmap. ✅ 
 
Managing a SaaS development project takes a lot of effort. 
 
If you don’t have a plan – you’re screwed. 
 
Here’s how we’re never screwed: 
 
𝟭. 𝗔 𝗖𝗿𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗹-𝗖𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿 𝗥𝗼𝗮𝗱𝗺𝗮𝗽 
 
Think of it as your project's North Star. 
 
Without a roadmap, you're wandering aimlessly. 
 
A roadmap outlines the journey, preventing detours and wrong turns.

Without a roadmap, you're wandering aimlessly. 
 
A roadmap outlines the journey, preventing detours and wrong turns. 
 
Tip: Make your roadmap detailed, yet flexible enough for unexpected changes. 
 
𝟮. 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 
 
You can’t drive an empty car. 
 
List your available resources:  
 
• Tools 
• People 
• Budget 
 
Assess them well before diving into the project. 
 
This ensures you're not left searching for fuel halfway through the journey. 
 
𝟯.

This ensures you're not left searching for fuel halfway through the journey. 
 
𝟯. 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗺𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗧𝗲𝗮𝗺 
 
Poor communication in your team can lead to costly mistakes. 
 
Establish clear channels and regular updates. 
 
Make sure everyone is on the same page. 
 
𝟰.

Establish clear channels and regular updates. 
 
Make sure everyone is on the same page. 
 
𝟰. 𝗔𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗖𝗵𝗮𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗲𝘀 
 
Things won't always go as planned. 
 
Expect detours and roadblocks. 
 
Plan for delays and budget overruns. 
 
Give yourself the cushion to handle surprises without panic.

What kind of SaaS founder are you?

(answer in the comments)

Two types of founders dominate the SaaS world:

1. Technical Founders

2. Business Founders

Let's look at each one. (think about what type you are as you read through this post)

Technical Founders:

- Can build things.
- Are natural problem solvers.
- Focus on scalable products.

Business Founders are:

- Industry experts.
- Customer-centric.
- Fundraising experts.

But the most successful founders?

They're a blend of both.

They evolve.

Technical folks learn the business.

Business folks learn tech.

So, how do you handle the transition from expert to owner?

Stop doing everything yourself.

Start delegating and trusting your team.

Recognize your strengths.

Improve your weaknesses.

Start delegating and trusting your team.

Improve your weaknesses.

5 tweaks to your SaaS user flow to delight your customers  
 
(and boost conversions): 
 
Small changes, big impact. 
 
If your users find navigating your site easy, they’ll stick around longer.  
 
Here are 5 tweaks to make that happen: 
 
𝟭. 𝗖𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿 𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆 𝗽𝗼𝗶𝗻𝘁𝘀 
 
Ensure call-to-actions (CTAs) stand out and tell users precisely where they’ll go next. 
 
𝟮.

𝟮. 𝗟𝗼𝗴𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗽𝘀 
 
Arrange steps in a sequence that feels natural—no surprises. 
 
𝟯. 𝗟𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 
 
Minimize distractions. Each step should have one clear focus. 
 
𝟰. 𝗙𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝗹𝗼𝗼𝗽𝘀 
 
Always let users know they’ve completed an action successfully.

A simple “Thank You” goes a long way. 
 
𝟱. 𝗠𝗼𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗲-𝗳𝗶𝗿𝘀𝘁 𝗱𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻 
 
Design for mobile first. That’s where most users are! 
 
Found these tips helpful? Share them!

4 critical questions you must ask to guarantee your SaaS product strategy aligns with your business goals: 
 
𝟭. 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘆 𝗯𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗮𝗹𝘀? 
 
Your strategy should walk hand-in-hand with your overarching goals.

Your strategy should walk hand-in-hand with your overarching goals.  
 
Define if you're aiming for: 
 
• Revenue growth 
• Market penetration 
• Heightened customer satisfaction 
 
This clarity directs your entire team, ensuring everyone's rowing in the same direction. 
 
𝟮. 𝗪𝗵𝗼 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘄𝗲 𝗯𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗱𝘂𝗰𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿? 
 
Identify your target audience with precision.

Identify your target audience with precision.  
 
Understand their demographics, psychographics, and preferences.  
 
This isn't just market research—it's about knowing their needs, challenges, and where they hang out.  
 
Without this insight, your product will miss the mark. 
 
𝟯. 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗹𝗲𝗺𝘀 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀 𝗶𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗹𝘃𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝘀𝗲𝗿𝘀?

A great product isn't just a tool. 
 
It soothes the pain. 
 
Whether it's saving time, cutting costs, or simplifying complex tasks, make sure your product addresses specific user frustrations.  
 
Use personas and user feedback to uncover these critical issues. 
 
𝟰. 𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝘄𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝘀𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀? 
 
Define the metrics that matter.  
 
Your KPIs should align with your primary goals, whether it's user engagement, revenue growth, or performance benchmarks.

Your KPIs should align with your primary goals, whether it's user engagement, revenue growth, or performance benchmarks.  
 
Regularly review and refine these metrics to keep growth on track. 
 
Getting clear answers to these ensures your digital strategy drives your business forward, not sideways.

4 types of churn rates crucial for SaaS founders  
 
(it’ll change your strategy) 
 
𝟭. 𝗖𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗿𝗻 
 
It’s the percentage of your customers who leave in a given period. 
 
Why it matters: 
 
• Directly impacts your revenue. 
• Indicates a problem with your product-market fit. 
 
𝟮. 𝗥𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘂𝗲 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗿𝗻 
 
This tells you the percentage of lost revenue from existing customers.

Why it matters: 
 
• Helps identify which segments are slipping away. 
• Reveals the financial impact of customer loss. 
 
𝟯. 𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘀𝘀 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗿𝗻 
 
Gross churn is the overall loss before accounting for new customers. 
 
Why it matters: 
 
• Highlights underlying retention issues. 
• Offers a clear picture of how much you're bleeding. 
 
𝟰. 𝗡𝗲𝘁 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗿𝗻 
 
This metric adjusts churn by including new revenue from existing customers. 
 
Why it matters: 
 
• Provides a comprehensive financial snapshot. 
• Balances losses and gains for better strategic decisions.

• Provides a comprehensive financial snapshot.

SaaS founder with no tech skills?

No problem.

Here are 7 ways to turn your idea into a successful product.

(without writing a single line of code)

1. Understand Your Industry

Your industry expertise is your secret weapon.

→ Leverage your existing knowledge and network.
→ Identify problems you're uniquely positioned to solve.

Familiarity breeds innovation, not contempt.

2. Identify Your Target Persona

Understanding your target user is crucial for product-market fit.

→ Create detailed user personas based on real data.
→ Conduct interviews with potential users to validate assumptions.

Know your users better than they know themselves because if you give them a product that ticks all the right boxes, you’ll have a customer for life. 

3.

3. Validate Without Code

Validate your idea before investing in development, so you don’t waste time, energy, and money building a product nobody wants or needs. 

→ Use no-code tools to create a prototype or MVP.
→ Run small-scale experiments to test key assumptions.

Fail fast, learn faster, and succeed sooner.

4. Engage a Technical Consultant

A technical advisor can bridge the gap between vision and execution.

→ Hire a consultant to review your product roadmap.
→ Partner with a product agency for initial scoping so you avoid costly mistakes and accelerate your time to market.

They speak geek, so you can focus on the business strategy. 

5. Workshops and Scoping Sessions

Avoid the chaos of random development and wasted resources by having a clear, actionable plan that guides your team from idea to execution.

→ Organize a product strategy workshop with key stakeholders.
→ Create a detailed product roadmap with clear milestones.

Do this, and you’ll minimize risks and maximize productivity, ensuring a successful product launch.

Plan the work, then work the plan.

6. Play It Safe (and Smart)

Minimizing risk is key to startup survival — don’t let a silly mistake ruin all of your hard work. 

→ Prioritize features ruthlessly for your MVP.
→ Set up regular check-ins to catch issues early.

Smart risks are the only risks worth taking.

7. Refine, Refine, Refine

Continuous improvement is the path to product excellence.

→ Implement a robust feedback loop with early users.
→ Schedule regular product review sessions with your team.

Your product is never finished — only shipped.

→ Schedule regular product review sessions with your team.

Your product is never finished — only shipped.

To recap:

You don't need to code to create a successful SaaS product.

You need:

Strategy.
Smart planning.
Market understanding.

A user flow isn't just a pretty map on your Figma board. 
 
It’s your SaaS money maker: 
 
A proper user flow will transform interest into action. 
 
But not many early-stage SaaS founders pay enough attention to it. 
 
Here are the 4 critical stages you need to focus on: 
 
𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝟭: Entry Point Discovery  
 
Your journey starts the moment users land on your page.  
 
Analyze:  
 
-> What devices they use most  
-> Initial impressions (first 5 seconds are crucial) 
-> Where users are coming from (social, ads, organic)  
 
 
Pro-tip: Use tools like Google Analytics to gain insights and optimize landing pages for all entry points.

𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝟮: First-Time Interaction  
 
Once they've arrived, what do they do next?  
 
Focus on:  
 
 
 
-> Most clicked elements  
-> Time spent on key pages 
-> Navigation paths (are they intuitive?)  
 
Pro-Tip: Heatmaps can help visualize user engagement and fine-tune your layout. 
 
𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝟯: Desire to Action  
 
Lead users from interest to intent by: 
 
-> Reducing clutter (minimize distractions) 
-> Offering value propositions early  
-> Utilizing clear CTAs  
 
 
Pro-tip: A/B test different CTAs and closely monitor which versions drive more conversions.

𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝟰: Closing & Retention  
 
Successful user flows don't just close deals. 
 
They keep the users coming back: 
 
-> Simplify the checkout process  
-> Use thank-you pages strategically (suggest next steps or offer discounts)  
-> Implement follow-ups (emails, retargeting ads) 
 
Pro-tip: Ensure post-purchase engagement to nurture long-term customer relationships.

How fragmented user journeys kill conversion rates 👇 
 
(even if your product looks great) 
 
User journeys matter. 
 
A fragmented one can tank your conversions.  
 
Here's how. 
 
First, mixed messages. 
 
When your journey lacks flow, users get mixed signals. They don't know what to do next. 
 
Second, multiple touchpoints. 
 
Too many steps? Users drop off. Less is more. 
 
Third, inconsistent branding. 
 
A scattered journey makes your brand look unprofessional. Users won’t trust it. 
 
The Solution? 
 
𝟭. 𝗖𝗹𝗮𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆 
 
Make each step clear and obvious. Guide users naturally. 
 
𝟮.

Guide users naturally. 
 
𝟮. 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗺𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 
 
Reduce unnecessary steps. Focus on what gets results. 
 
𝟯. 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 
 
Ensure branding is uniform across every touchpoint. Keep the experience seamless. 
 
Want more conversions? Fix that journey.

Choosing a Digital Product Agency is like walking a tightrope. 

One wrong step could lead to missed deadlines, budget overruns, and even legal issues. 

Yet, as you start your search, you'll find agencies making all sorts of attractive promises. 

So how can you separate the wheat from the chaff? 

Here are some questions to ask:

1- How will you help us stand out from our competitors?

Your chosen agency should help clarify your product's unique value proposition. This is key to crafting a product strategy that meets your customer's specific needs. 

2- What is your process for translating vision into reality?

A good agency will have a systematic approach to turning your idea into a tangible product. This could involve stakeholder interviews, user-centric design, prototyping, roadmapping and design thinking.

This could involve stakeholder interviews, user-centric design, prototyping, roadmapping and design thinking.

3- How do you ensure product strategy aligns with business goals?

Look at their previous work to judge their capabilities. Their client experiences and case studies can give you a clear picture of their approach and industry knowledge.

4- How do you handle MVP development and iteration?

MVP development is critical for SaaS products. An effective agency will have a system in place for managing this process.

5- What makes your agency a true partner in product development?

Look for signs of transparency, co-creation, iteration and project management. These indicate a partnership rather than a mere customer-vendor relationship.

6- How do you support product growth and scalability post-launch?

These indicate a partnership rather than a mere customer-vendor relationship.

6- How do you support product growth and scalability post-launch?

A great agency should stick around post-launch to address issues, develop features and optimize performance.

In conclusion, collaboration is the key to a successful partnership with a digital product agency. 

By being involved in the development process, you can ensure that the final product meets both your goals and your customers' needs.

Remember, choosing an agency is not a decision to be rushed. Take your time, ask the right questions and make an informed choice.

Every month, the products we've built generate $10M+ in revenue for our clients.

What NPS score should your SaaS aspire to? 
 
Finding the exact number isn’t easy. 
 
The range of domains SaaS caters to and the number of apps available on the market make it nearly impossible to estimate an average SaaS NPS. 
 
The NPS definition divides customers into 3 groups: 
 
𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗺𝗼𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀 (𝟵-𝟭𝟬): Loyal customers happy to recommend you to others (and bring new customers through word of mouth) 
 
𝗣𝗮𝘀𝘀𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 (𝟳-𝟴): They are not unhappy customers but will most likely churn when a better

(𝟳-𝟴): They are not unhappy customers but will most likely churn when a better deal appears 
 
𝗗𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘀 (𝟬-𝟲): Dissatisfied users who may complain about your app to others and hurt your reputation 
 
For the longest time, an average NPS of 50 for SaaS was the benchmark.

Your bootstrapped Freemium SaaS will fail. 
 
But I can fix it for you. 👇 
 
Freemium is a numbers game. 
 
To sustain this business model, you need distribution channels that pour infinite users into your funnel for low CAC (Customer Acquisition Cost). 
 
However, building acquisition channels like these takes time and money that bootstrappers cannot afford.  
 
The revenue you take from your paying customers must cover the costs of both your free users AND keeping your acquisition channels active. 
 
Bootstrappers need ROI, not sunk costs. 
 
If I were you, I would offer a generous Free Trial instead. 
 
If you add just one well-oiled distribution channel to this model, your ROI will be 10-100x.📈💰

The best way to 10x your SaaS MVP:  
 
1/10 the functionality you build. 
 
I've been doing MVPs for 15 years, and what most founders want to build is too much. 
 
Seriously. 
 
Take my advice: 
- Remove 50% of desired functionality 
- Sleep on it 
- Remove 50% again 
 
What remains is your Minimum Viable Product. 
 
Yes, there are exceptions. 
 
Yes, there may be industry-specific regulations you need to comply with that require additional functionality. 
 
But if you ever need to decide whether a nice-to-have functionality is necessary for going to market...  
 
It's probably not.

Why let flat pricing flatten your SaaS growth? 📉 
 
Transforming to usage-based pricing might put your SaaS back on track. 
 
Here's why it's not just a trend but a strategic move: 
 
𝟭. 𝗜𝗻𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿 𝗔𝗰𝗾𝘂𝗶𝘀𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: Lower barriers to entry mean you can attract more customers initially. 
 
𝟮.

𝟮. 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗥𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘂𝗲: As customers find value, they naturally expand their usage, leading to higher revenue.

3 Tactics that Help Your Startup MVP Survive the First Encounter with the Customer👇 
 
But first, let's put things right. 
 
We're in a mobile-first age. More than half of web traffic comes from mobile devices.  
 
If your MVP doesn't cater to this, you overlook a massive market slice. 
 
A poor mobile experience pushes potential users away. If your MVP isn't mobile-friendly, you're laying out your competitors' welcome mat. 
 
Google loves mobile-responsive designs, too.  
 
With a mobile-friendly MVP, you're pleasing your users and the search engine gods determining your discoverability. 
 
Now, here are 3 less conventional tactics I swear by to ensure mobile responsiveness: 
 
🟢 1. Design for Thumbs 
Most smartphones are used one-handed.

Design for Thumbs 
Most smartphones are used one-handed. Design your MVP with this in mind.  
 
Make it thumb-friendly. 
 
🟢 2. Minimise Input 
The fewer the inputs required on a mobile device, the better.  
 
Leverage autocomplete functions, dropdown menus, and checkboxes to make the process smoother. 
 
🟢 3. Test on Actual Devices 
Emulators are great, but nothing beats testing on an actual device.  
 
Different devices and browsers might render your MVP differently. 
 
Your MVP is not just a smaller desktop application version. It's a different beast altogether. 
 
Try these tactics out for your next MVP.

Let's get one thing straight. 👇 
 
Your MVP isn't meant to be perfect. 
 
While conventional wisdom might advise you to set sky-high goals for your Minimum Viable Product launch, I'd like to flip that idea on its head.  
 
Here's my counterintuitive approach: Aim for the achievable. 
 
Yes, you heard it right.  
 
The purpose of an MVP is to test market waters, not to make a grand splash.  
 
It's about learning, adapting, and improving. So why burden it with unrealistic expectations? 
 
Every potential hiccup is a valuable lesson in disguise.  
 
First and foremost, focus on functionality over finesse. Your MVP needs to solve a problem, not look pretty.

First and foremost, focus on functionality over finesse. Your MVP needs to solve a problem, not look pretty.  
 
Next, measure the success of your MVP not by its initial sales but by the feedback it generates.

Finally, overnight success is a lie.  
 
Instead, aim to attract a small, dedicated tribe of early adopters. 
 
These people will become your product's champions, propelling your MVP from a simple concept to a market-ready solution. 
 
So, let's put the grandeur aside.  
 
Set realistic, achievable goals for your MVP launch. Adopt a learning and growth mindset, and let that be your measure of success.

🔴 5/ No credible reviews to show 

Avoid choosing a service with no credible reviews or case studies of startups they’ve helped to build MVP and grow. 

It raises doubts about their reliability and should be considered a 'no.'

🔴 6/ Not clear project management process 

An efficient project management process is crucial for timely delivery. 

Make sure your development partner has one in place.

Make sure your development partner has one in place.

🔴 7/ Their solutions are not scalable and future-proof

Choose a team with a long-term vision for your product, and ensure that the MVP is scalable and future-proof. 

Make sure they design your software with a modular architecture that allows new features to be added without disrupting the existing code. 

They also should build your software on top of a modern technology stack that is well-supported and likely to remain relevant for years to come.

This will help you avoid facing major issues in the later stages of the product life cycle.

🔴 8/ No Post-Dev Support 

Choose a development team that provides ongoing support and insights even after the successful completion of your MVP. 

Without post-dev guidance, your product might struggle in the market.

Without post-dev guidance, your product might struggle in the market.

🔴 9/ They’re not really interested in knowing you 

Understanding your business is crucial for a successful MVP.

A team without interest may result in a mismatched solution.

How building an MVP literally saves you money: 
 
Suppose you're making a fitness app.  
 
You have to choose how to include a rest timer, a key feature. 
 
One way involves a voice-activated rest timer that users can trigger by saying the app's name out loud. 
 
The other requires users to open the app and click a button to start the rest timer. 
 
You presume the voice-activated timer will be more beneficial as you can do it hands-free.  
 
You build an MVP with this version and approach a few users for feedback. 
 
Turns out, your presumption was wrong. 
 
The users felt weird talking to their phones while in the gym full of others. 
 
They stopped using the feature after the first try. 
 
Now, imagine you said: 
 
“I’m sure users will love this idea.

They stopped using the feature after the first try. 
 
Now, imagine you said: 
 
“I’m sure users will love this idea. No need for an MVP.” 
 
It’s like calling for a disaster. 
 
MVP is vital because it turns opinions into facts. 
 
It gives you as much learning about your customers’ needs as possible. 
 
And the more you know about their needs, the bigger your wallet becomes.

Did you know that Instagram started as a social media game? 
 
They even got $500,000 in funding – until: 
 
Kevin Systrom, Instagram’s founder, built an HTML5 prototype of IG (or Burbn, as it was called then) and shared this prototype with the first users. 
 
The main features of Burbn let users check in locations, share plans with friends, and earn points by posting photos. 
 
But when the early adopters started testing it, it turned out that the only 3 features used were posting pictures, liking, and commenting on them. 
 
Based on this feedback, Kevin and Mike (Instagram’s co-founder) scraped most of the features of Burbn and spent weeks rebuilding the app for weeks before launching it in 2010. 
 
The result?

The result? Thousands of downloads and overheated servers hours after the launch. 
 
You see, one of the biggest reasons for Instagram's huge success is its founders’ willingness to listen to their customers.  
 
They didn’t presume anything, wasting time and money on building tons of features. 
 
Instead, they built an MVP with core functionality and showed it to the public.

A simple framework to define a bullet-proof SaaS value proposition: 
 
AND - BUT - THEREFORE (ABT) 
 
It’s so good because it accounts for something most core value propositions overlook: 
 
Differentiator. 
 
Aka, how your product stands out from 1000s alternatives in the market. 
 
How to use it?

Aka, how your product stands out from 1000s alternatives in the market. 
 
How to use it? 
 
Start with setting the stage: 
 
👉 “Most local small businesses want to use digital marketing...” 
Now, highlight what really hides behind the need you just mentioned: 
 
👉 “…AND increase their reach beyond the boundaries of traditional marketing methods…” 
 
Next, you add a contradiction – something that stopping them from achieving their desired outcome: 
 
👉 “...BUT they have limited time and money to invest in establishing a long-term online presence…” 
 
Finally, you state what you’re going to do about this contradiction: 
 
“...THEREFORE, our AI social media tool automates creating and distributing highly engaging digital content based on the business’ real-time analytics.” 
 
This framework amplifies the impact your product will have on the target audience.

Plus, it paints a clear picture of the direction your business should take to spark potential users’ attention. 
 
Now, it’s your turn: 
 
What’s your ABT?

Ever heard of a Reverse Trial?  
 
Here's how it’s boosting SaaS conversions! 
 
We are all familiar with free trials and freemium plans. However, the concept of a SaaS reverse trial might be new to many.  
 
Visualise this scenario: a customer gains access to all the features of a product for a certain period before having to downgrade to a freemium plan.  
 
This model has already been adopted by significant players like Toggl, Canva, Calendly, and Notion, and they are all experiencing the advantages of this innovative approach.  
 
So, what sets the reverse trial apart: 
 
1. Higher conversion rates  
 
The reverse trial outperforms free trials and freemium plans in terms of conversion rates.

Higher conversion rates  
 
The reverse trial outperforms free trials and freemium plans in terms of conversion rates. Customers, after experiencing the full product, are more likely to upgrade. 
 
2. Enhanced vendor-client relationships 
 
Offering customers full product access from the beginning can foster trust and build stronger relationships. 
 
3. Improved retention 
 
Customers who have experienced all the features are more likely to remain loyal. Hence, the reverse trial can significantly increase customer retention. 
 
4. Superior onboarding experience 
 
The reverse trial allows users to truly understand your product, potentially improving the onboarding experience.  
 
However, the reverse trial might not be suitable for every product.

However, the reverse trial might not be suitable for every product.  
 
If your product is challenging to learn, has low usage, or incurs significant service costs, the reverse trial might not be an optimal choice.  
 
But for the products that can leverage its potential, the reverse trial can be a game-changer.  
 
Love to hear your thoughts on the reverse trial method!  
 
Have you tried it for your SaaS product?

What if I told you 'minimum' in MVP isn't about features at all?🤔 
 
We've all been misled.  
 
The 'Minimum' in Minimum Viable Product (MVP) has long been associated with the product features. But think again! 
 
The term 'Minimum' doesn't refer to the scarcity of features.  
 
Instead, it's about the essence of value. It's about delivering an experience that solves a problem with the least effort. 
 
Imagine a bicycle. The 'Minimum' isn't a wheel, a pedal, or a handlebar.  
 
It's the movement - the ability to get you from point A to B.  
 
The 'Minimum' is the fundamental value proposition - the bare bones of what your product offers that can answer the consumer's pain points.

Let's shift our mindset. Let's prioritize the value we deliver over the number of features we build.  
 
Let's build MVPs that are minimal in effort, not in value. 
 
Next time you think about your MVP, remember - the 'Minimum' is about the essence, not the excess.🥇

Startups and their obsession with funding. 
 
The race for venture capital may be diverting our focus from what truly matters. 
 
The real success of a startup isn't measured just by its ability to secure funding but by its capacity to build transformative solutions. 
 
We often see entrepreneurs in a race to secure funding for their SaaS startups, but have you ever stopped to ponder if your venture needs that capital injection right now? 
 
Consider bootstrapping.  
 
Why? It maintains control. When investors come on board, they bring their expectations, timelines, and pressures. By self-funding, you retain full control over your vision and strategic direction. 
 
Here's another angle. Bootstrapping forces frugality.

Here's another angle. Bootstrapping forces frugality.  
 
You become smarter about where each dollar goes, which can lead to leaner operations and more innovative solutions. 
 
Then comes resilience. 🛡️ 
 
Bootstrapped startups learn to weather storms early. The journey is tough, but the resultant resilience is a competitive advantage. 
 
Lastly, there's the validation angle.  
 
Achieving profitability or a strong customer base without external funding is a powerful signal to future investors about the viability of your business model. 
 
Now, none of this is to say that funding is bad.  
 
It's just not always necessary, especially in the early stages. 
 
Remember, every business is unique. What works for others might not work for you.

Remember, every business is unique. What works for others might not work for you.  
 
So, step back, assess your situation, and decide if you really need that funding now or can it wait. 
 
The bottom line: Don't rush for funding.  
 
- Be patient.  
- Bootstrap.  
- Build resilience.  
- Validate your business.  
 
Then, when you do go for funding, it'll be on your terms. 
 
Think about it. Share your thoughts below. ✍️

Are you aware of the REAL customer acquisition cost in your SaaS venture? 😱 
 
It's not just about the monetary value but also the time and resources dedicated to landing new clients.  
 
Many startups focus on 'customer acquisition at all costs', forgetting that they may create an unsustainable business model.💸 
 
The key to sustainability: understanding your Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC) and Lifetime Value (LTV).  
 
These metrics are vital to determining how much you should reasonably spend acquiring customers.  
 
For instance, if your LTV:CAC ratio is 1:3, you spend three times more to acquire a customer than you'll ever earn from them.  
 
In the long term, this is a surefire recipe for failure.

In the long term, this is a surefire recipe for failure. 💥 
 
Strive for a balanced ratio where your earnings from customers outweigh what you spend acquiring them. 
 
In essence, winning isn't about acquiring as many customers as possible— it's about gaining profitable customers.  
 
Work smarter, not harder.🥇

Rejected a lot before landing your first SaaS customers?  
 
One must be prepared for an uphill battle in the SaaS industry. It's rarely a smooth journey, more often than not, it's a game of persistence. 
 
Most SaaS product pioneers will tell you that rejection is part and parcel of startup development.  
 
Every 'No' face is another stepping stone towards coveted 'Yes'.  
 
In my experience, it's all about how you deal with these rejections that define your path to success. 
 
By analysing why the client didn't opt for your solution, you learn about needs and requirements that may have yet to be anticipated initially.  
 
This information can serve as dynamic feedback, aiding in refining and improving the MVP app development process. 
 
Moreover, rejection teaches perseverance and resilience.

This information can serve as dynamic feedback, aiding in refining and improving the MVP app development process. 
 
Moreover, rejection teaches perseverance and resilience. Both are invaluable traits of entrepreneurship. 
 
Laugh in the face of rejection: every setback is a setup for a comeback.  
 
So next time a prospect turns down your SaaS solution, don't be disheartened.  
 
Instead, take it as an opportunity to:  
learn 
improve  
and bounce back stronger!

This is how we kickstart every week at our Product Agency. 

And why you should do this too!

We start every week with our Monday Kick-off call.

And why you should do this too!

We start every week with our Monday Kick-off call. It keeps the company aligned: 
✅ Current status of all projects
✅ Occasional problems to be solved
✅ Milestones planned for the week

Moreover, this is where important announcements concerning the company are first made: 
- New clients
- Clients leaving (hopefully, not 😀 )
- Personnel updates
- Policy changes

Participants:
- Head of Production (leads the conversation)
- Project Managers
- Design Team lead
- Founders (Mate & me)

Agenda:
👯 Friendly chat to set the mood
👩‍🏫 Product Team managers report
🎨 Design Lead reports
👩‍🔬 HR reports
🗒 Create actionable tasks when needed

That's it.

Sounds simple, right? But it's so powerful!

We are a systems & processes based company. 

Therefore, we delegate everything we can. 

And then, we don't micromanage. 🚫 

The teams are empowered to manage themselves. 👑 

The teams set the goal together every Monday and let them do their job. 

We have been doing this for years, becoming one of the strongest pillars of our internal systems that power our predictable SaaS product development process. 🥇 

Do you have week-starter rituals? Share it in the comments below!
